questions.text: Efferent from cerebellar cortex is through which cell:
questions.solution:
Purkinje cells are the only output neurons (efferent neurons) from the cerebellar cortex.

The Purkinje cells are the largest neurons in the cerebellum. Their axons, which are the only output from the cerebellar cortex, project to the deep cerebellar nuclei, especially the dentate nucleus, where they form inhibitory synapses.

questions.text: Which of the following forms complex I of the electron transport chain?
questions.solution:
Complex I of the electron transport chain (ETC) is NADH-Q oxidoreductase.

The ETC constitutes 4 enzyme complexes:

  • Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase
  • Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase
  • Complex III: Q-cytochrome c oxidoreductase
  • Complex IV: cytochrome c oxidase

Components of complex I: FMN and Fe-S complex 

Mechanism: NADH-Q oxidoreductase catalyzes the transfer of electrons, from NADH to coenzyme Q, along with the transfer of four H+ across the membrane.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CSF sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci. 

Pathogenesis & clinical features:

  • The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx. From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.
  • Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages. 
  • Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: Which among the following is a highly emetogenic anticancer drug?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin is a highly emetogenic anticancer drug. Cisplatin causes marked nausea and vomiting in almost all cases and is usually administered along with anti-emetic regimens.

This can usually be controlled with 5HT3 receptor antagonists, neurokinin (NK1) receptor antagonists (e.g., aprepitant), and high-dose corticosteroids.

questions.text: What is a Molotov cocktail?
questions.solution:
Molotov cocktail is an incendiary bomb that is thrown by hand.

In this crude type of bomb, a bottle is filled with gasoline and a rag to serve as a wick, the wick is lit and thrown at the target.

questions.text: A patient post-tonsillectomy in the recovery room starts bleeding from the operative site. On examination, blood clots are seen. What will be your immediate management?

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of reactionary hemorrhage post-tonsillectomy and the immediate management is to shift the patient to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the bleeding vessel.

Hemorrhage is a common complication of tonsillectomy. It can be primary, reactionary, or secondary:

Primary hemorrhage occurs at the time of operation. It can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours. It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or blood pressure returning to normal. It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. Ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels is done under anesthesia if the above measures fail.

Secondary hemorrhage is usually seen between the 5th to 10th postoperative day. It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. Removal of the clot, topical application of dilute adrenaline or hydrogen peroxide with pressure usually suffice. IV antibiotics are given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated if bleeding continues.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of watering, redness, foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis. It is most commonly associated with contact lens wear. It can also be associated with ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles.

The patients usually present with redness, foreign body sensation, increased mucus production, itching, blurring, and loss of contact lens tolerance. On examination, giant papillae are seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae.

Papillae are reddish, flat-topped raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva These are the hyperplasia of the normal vascular system with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium.

The image below shows papillae in the tarsal conjunctiva.

Treatment: The offending cause should be removed. Mast cell stabilizers such as sodium cromoglycate, and drugs like azelastine and olopatadine which have combined antihistamine and mast cell stabilizing effects are effective. Steroids can be used for resistant cases.

Other options:

Option A - In acute trachoma, sago grain follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

Image showing sago grain follicles in trachoma

 

Option B - In follicular conjunctivitis, follicles are seen. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses. Follicles are greyish white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer.

Image showing follicles

 

Option D - In spring catarrh (vernal catarrh), cobblestone appearance is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva, ropy discharge, and Maxwell–Lyon sign are present. Horner-Tranta’s spots that are discrete whitish raised dots along the limbus can also be seen. It is more common during summer.

Image showing Horner-Tranta’s spots.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: Lung malignancy is most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis is most commonly associated with Mesotheliomas,  pleural malignancy. 

Asbestos-related diseases include:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Pleural effusion
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Laryngeal, ovarian and colon carcinomas

Asbestosis:

  • Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis that occurs after 5-10 years of exposure to asbestos. However, once established, it progresses even in the further removal of the worker from its contact. Asbestosis affects the basal part of the lung causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis.
  • Asbestos is of 2 types i.e Serpentine/Chrysolite variety and Amphibole type
  • Amphibole type has the following varieties:
    • Crocidolite(blue)
    • Amosite(brown)
    • Anthrophyllite(white)
  • Sputum shows asbestos body, which are asbestos fibres coated with fibrin.
  • They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea and predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
  • X-ray shows peripheral reticular opacities predominantly in the lower zones. HRCT shows subpleural fibrotic lines, irregular opacities, traction bronchiectasis and honeycombing. Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years).
  • The complications that can occur are
    • Pulmonary fibrosis 
    • Carcinoma of the lung 
    • Malignancy of the Gastrointestinal tract
    • Mesothelioma of the pleura

Preventive measures:

  • Using a safer type of Asbestos (chrysolite and amosite)
  • Substituting other insulants like glass fibre, mineral wool, calcium silicate, plastic foams etc
  • Dust control
  • Periodic examination of workers
  • Continuing research

questions.text: You are part of a rural health camp organized under Project Axshya. Which of the following diseases does it aim to control?
questions.solution:
Project Axshya was launched in 2010 to control TB. Axshya means free from TB which is the ultimate goal of the project and the National TB Elimination Programme.

Project Axshya is being implemented by the International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (known simply as The Union). The project works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between the government and civil society.

The guiding principles of project Axshya are:

  • Universal access to quality TB services
  • Community participation in TB care and control
  • Sustainable interventions and equitable distribution of project benefits with social and gender sensitivity

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the hospital due to fever and abdominal pain. He was diagnosed to have a cirrhotic liver 2 years back. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count of 360 cell/ microliter. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cefotaxime is the drug of choice in this patient.

This patient’s clinical features are suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).

SBP is a common and severe complication of ascites characterized by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source.

The most common organisms are Escherichia coli and other gut bacteria.

The diagnosis of SBP is made when the fluid sample has an absolute neutrophil count >250/μL.

The first line of empiric treatment is with a third-generation cephalosporin because the majority of cases are caused by aerobic gram-negative microbes such as E. coli, with cefotaxime being the most commonly used antibiotic.

In patients who have had an episode(s) of SBP and recovered, once-weekly administration of antibiotics is used as prophylaxis for recurrent SBP.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presented with miosis, ptosis, and anhydrosis on the left side with difficulty in walking, dysphagia, and dysarthria. On examination, he was found to have a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the body and the left side of the face. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is left-sided Wallenberg’s syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome).

In the given case scenario, there is contralateral hemisensory loss of pain and temperature, with ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome and sensory loss on face associated with dysphagia and dysarthria which are characteristic of this condition.

Note: Lateral medullary (Wallenberg’s) syndrome is due to occlusion of the vertebral, posterior inferior cerebellar, superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries.

Structures affected on the ipsilateral side:

  • Fifth nerve nucleus and descending tract: Pain, numbness, impaired sensation over the face
  • Cerebellar fibers, spinocerebellar tract: Ataxia
  • Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus, diplopia, oscillopsia, vertigo, nausea, vomiting
  • Descending sympathetic tract: Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating)
  • Ninth and Tenth nerve fibers: Dysphagia, hoarseness, paralysis of the palate, paralysis of vocal cord, diminished gag reflex.

Structures affected on the contralateral side:

  • Spinothalamic tract: Impaired pain and thermal sense over half the body, sometimes face

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with backache. Urine examination revealed nephrotic range proteinuria with Bence-Jones proteins. Laboratory reports showed hypercalcemia.  A renal biopsy specimen stained by congo red seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. Which of the major fibril protein is accumulated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from multiple myeloma. The major fibril protein accumulated in this patient is AL (amyloid light chain) protein.

The above clinical scenario of backache, proteinuria with Bence-Jones protein, hypercalcemia are suggestive of multiple myeloma. The image showing a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized microscopy is indicative of amyloid accumulation in the organ. In multiple myeloma, the amyloid is made from the light chain of immunoglobulins (chiefly λ type). 

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. The abnormal fibrils are obtained by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind to proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid is an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Microscopy :

All types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils and are demonstrated on electron microscopy. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. The stain used for amyloid deposits is congo red staining. It imparts pink to red color to the amyloid under ordinary light. Under polarised microscopy, congo red-stained amyloid shows apple-green birefringence.

Other options:

Option A-  Amyloid β2 microglobulin(Aβ2M) fibrillar protein is seen in hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis in chronic renal failure.

Option B- Amyloid-associated (AA) fibrillar protein is seen in secondary systemic amyloidosis and familial Mediterranean fever.

Option D- Amyloid transthyretin (ATTR) fibrillar protein is seen in the mutated form in familial amyloidotic polyneuropathies and in an unmutated form in systemic senile amyloidosis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient was referred to you with features of pituitary adenoma and testicular tumor. While going through his radiological reports, you saw the presence of parathyroid adenoma, and his chromosomal studies show a mutation in the CDKN1B gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CDKN1B gene : Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1b gene
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of pituitary adenoma, parathyroid adenoma, testicular tumor, and a mutation in the CDKN1B gene is suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 4 (MEN 4).

MEN 4 is an autosomal dominant endocrine tumor syndrome. It occurs due to the germline mutation in the CDKN1B gene in chromosome 12.

MEN 4 often presents with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, or neuroendocrine cervical cancer with adrenal or renal tumors. 

The clinical presentation in MEN 4 is almost similar to MEN1. The difference between MEN1 and MEN4 is in the germline mutation, where MEN 1 occurs due to the mutation of the MEN1 gene.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) is a group of autosomal dominant disorders characterized by tumors involving two or more endocrine glands. Depending on the chromosomal location of germline mutation they are divided into four major forms as MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), and MEN 4. MEN 1 is the most common among the four types. 

Other Options:

Option B- MEN 3 is also known as MEN 2B. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid features. In contrast with MEN2A, parathyroid hyperplasia is not seen in MEN 2B.

Option C- MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary carcinoma thyroid, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma.

Option D- MEN 1 is also known as Wermer's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation in the MEN 1 gene. It is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)

questions.text: Which of the following types of hepatic adenomas is associated with an increased risk of malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
β-catenin mutated subtype of hepatic adenoma is associated with an increased risk of malignant transformation.

The 2017 Bordeaux molecular-pathologic classification of hepatocellular adenomas (HCA) includes six subtypes:

  1. HNF1A-inactivated HCA 
  2. Inflammatory HCA 
  3. β-catenin exon 3 mutated HCA
  4. β-catenin exon 7/8 mutated HCA 
  5. Sonic hedgehog activated HCA 
  6. Unclassified HCA

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell into a manhole and injured his perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of the urethra, and swelling of the penis and scrotum was seen. What is the site of injury?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of a blow to the perineum, blood at the tip of the meatus, swelling of the penis and scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the bulbar urethra.

Urethral injuries can be classified into:

 Type Proximal urethral injury Distal urethral injury
Site of injury
  • Prostatic urethra
  • Membranous urethra
  • Bulbar urethra
  • Penile urethra
Mechanism Secondary to pelvic fracture

Occurs due to a blow to the perineum by:

  • Straddle injury
  • Loose manhole covering
  • Gymnasium accidents
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)
  • Deep perineal hematoma
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Perineal hematoma (Butterfly hematoma)


Note: Urinary bladder rupture occurs due to an injury to the suprapubic region. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is more common and associated with pelvic fracture. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or a fall on the distended bladder. It manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male sustains thoracic spinal cord injury in a road accident and develops neurogenic shock. 
In this patient with neurogenic shock, hypotension will be associated with-
questions.solution:
Neurogenic shock is associated with bradycardia and not tachycardia.

Features of Neurogenic shock:

  • Neurogenic shock is usually secondary to spinal cord injuries due to vertebral body fractures of the cervical or high thoracic region that disrupts the sympathetic outflow. 
  • Loss of vasoconstrictor impulses results in decreased peripheral resistance, decreased venous return and decreased cardiac output, resulting in shock.

The classic description of neurogenic shock consists of:

  • Decreased blood pressure associated with bradycardia (absence of reflexive tachycardia due to disrupted sympathetic discharge).
  • Warm extremities (due to loss of peripheral vasoconstriction)
  • Motor and sensory deficits indicative of a spinal cord injury
  • Radiographic evidence of a vertebral fracture

questions.text: Which among the following is the most carcinogenic gene in ovarian cancer?
questions.solution:
BRCA 1 is more carcinogenic than BRCA 2.

  • 5–10% of malignant ovarian tumors are genetic.
  • BRCA 1 gene is on chromosome 17q.
  • BRCA 2 gene is on chromosome 13q.
  • BRCA 1 is associated with Hereditary Breast Ovarian Cancer syndrome.

Note: Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) is associated with malignancy of colon, ovary, and endometrium.

questions.text: The following hysterosalpingogram indicates
questions.solution:
The given image is of a hysterosalpingogram showing the contrast dye filling an irregulary shaped edometrial cavity often described as "moth-eaten" appearance. Hence, it is Asherman syndrome.

The presence of intrauterine adhesions is called Asherman syndrome. Destruction of the basal endometrium prevents endometrial thickening, thus no tissue is produced. Endometrial damage may follow vigorous curettage in association with PPH, miscarriage, or elective abortion.

If intrauterine adhesions are suspected:

  • Radiological evaluation of the uterine cavity is performed.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) offers information regarding both uterine cavity and fallopian tube patency.
  • Saline infusion sonography provides an excellent alternative to HSG.
  • Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.

The above image is a hysteroscopic image of intrauterine adhesions found with Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with suspected tubal pregnancy underwent transvaginal ultrasound which was inconclusive. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the next step would be to confirm the tubal ectopic by measuring serum β hCG. This can be used to differentiate tubal ectopic pregnancy from missed abortion and early intrauterine pregnancy. 

If the level is ≥2000 IU/L, ectopic pregnancy is suspected. If the level is <1500 IU/L, a repeat serum β hCG is taken after 48 hours. If the levels are:

  • Doubled - early intrauterine pregnancy
  • Decreased - abortion
  • Increased but less than doubled value - ectopic pregnancy

Investigations for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Serum β hCG - lower levels compared to normal pregnancy, prolonged doubling time
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - empty uterine cavity, fluid in pouch of Douglas, adnexal mass
  • Colour Doppler - ring of fire pattern
  • Laparoscopy 
  • Dilatation and curettage - decidua identified without villi
  • Serum progesterone 
  • Culdocentesis 

Diagnostic laparoscopy may be done when the diagnosis is still uncertain after serial β-hCG monitoring and repeat ultrasonography. In high-risk situations, such as a history of previous ectopic pregnancy, earlier diagnostic laparoscopy is considered.

questions.text: The chromosomal abnormality associated in a neonate with prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet is most probably _________
questions.solution:
Prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet are all features of Edwards syndrome, i.e., Trisomy 18.

Trisomy 18 - Edwards syndrome:

  • Low birth weight
  • Closed fists with index finger overlapping the 3rd digit and the 5th digit overlapping the 4th
  • Narrow hips with limited abduction
  • Short sternum
  • Rocker-bottom feet
  • Microcephaly
  • Prominent occiput
  • Micrognathia
  • Cardiac and renal malformations
  • Intellectual disability

questions.text: A patient who had applied plaster to his right leg for a tibial shaft fracture ,now presents with severe pain in the leg. On examination, the distal pulses are absent, on passive stretching the pain increases, and on opening the plaster, the leg appears edematous and numerous blisters are seen. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what would be the most appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Opening of the plaster is sufficient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests acute compartment syndrome, and it is treated immediately with fasciotomy.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps:

  • Pain: Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle is highly sensitive to touch. On the passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 
  • Paresthesia: Paresthesia and hypoesthesia may be noted due to compression of nerves traversing the affected compartment. They are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor: Pallor of the skin may not always be seen. The skin outside the compartment may be normally perfused, as only the intra-compartmental perfusion may be affected.
  • Paralysis: Paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness: Usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as the differential pressure (ΔP). A differential pressure (ΔP) of less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals) is an indication for immediate compartment decompression.

Treatment: The threatened compartment must be promptly decompressed, merely splitting the plaster is utterly useless and the limb must be nursed flat, elevating the limb causes further decrease in end capillary pressure and aggravates the muscle ischemia. In the case of compartment syndrome in the leg, Fasciotomy means opening all four compartments. Wounds to be left open and inspected 2 days later, if tissues are healthy, the wounds can be sutured. If there is muscle necrosis, debridement to be carried out.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use stopped drinking. Three days later, he was brought to the emergency department with disorientation, tremors, hallucinations, and hypertension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of a chronic alcoholic man brought in with complaints of disorientation, tremors, hallucinations, and hypertension is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens occurs after 2-4 days of abstinence in a heavy or chronic drinker. It is precipitated by conditions like hepatitis and pancreatitis. It usually resolves in one week. The characteristic clinical features include:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation in time and place
  • Distractibility and lack of attention
  • Visual, auditory, and/or tactile hallucinations
  • Autonomic disturbance with tachycardia, fever, hypertension, sweating, and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia
  • Insomnia
  • Dehydration with electrolyte imbalance

Delirium tremens is treated using benzodiazepines starting with a higher dosage which is gradually tapered as withdrawal symptoms disappear. In cases of chronic alcohol use, vitamin deficiency (especially thiamine) may be co-existing and hence bolus doses of thiamine are given to prevent/treat Wernicke encephalopathy.

Other options:

Option A- Alcoholic hallucinosis is characterized by the presence of hallucinations (usually auditory) during partial or complete abstinence. However, the other symptoms given in the clinical scenario are not seen.

Option B- Korsakoff’s psychosis: It is seen n patients with chronic alcohol use usually followed by Wernicke’s encephalopathy, together referred to as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. Patients with Korsakoff's psychosis present with memory disturbances, which is not seen in the given case.

Option C- Marchiafava-Bignami disease is a rare disorder seen in chronic alcoholics, associated with epilepsy, ataxia, dysarthria, hallucinations, spastic limb paralysis, and deterioration of personality and intellectual functioning.

questions.text: What ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is given during CPR in an adult if 2 rescuers are present?
questions.solution:
During cardiopulmonary resuscitation of adults, the ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 irrespective of the number of rescuers.

In infants and children, the ratio is 30:2 for a single rescuer and 15:2 if 2 or more rescuers are present.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

Related Pearl: Basic Life Support (BLS) Algorithm

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with an increased nighttime itching and lesions that are more during the winter months?
questions.solution:
Skin lesions that increase during the winter months and that cause more itching during the nighttime are seen with scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic skin infection that is transmitted through the means of close personal contact/fomites. It is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis or human itch mite. It leads to severe pruritis, excoriating papules, and burrows. The pruritis typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. In adults, the face is often spared. Typical sites include the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, elbows, axillae, buttocks, and genitalia. The typical lesions of scabies are burrows.

The following techniques can be used to diagnose scabies:

  • Skin scraping and microscopy - The material is scraped off with a blunt scalpel and is placed in mineral oil on a microscope slide. The presence of mites, eggs, fragments of eggshells, or scybala (hardened masses of faeces) confirms the diagnosis.
  • Dermoscopy - Useful for detecting burrows and visualizing their contents.
    • 10x magnification - mini triangle sign, maturing eggs that show minute heads of maturing mites within the egg.
    • 40x magnification - The mite in its burrow resembles a ‘jet‐with‐contrail’.
  • Adhesive-tape test - After firmly applying the adhesive side of the tape onto an appropriate skin lesion of patient, the tape is pulled off and transferred directly onto a slide for microscopy to visualize the mites.
  • Skin biopsy.

Treatment:

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% Lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.
  • Ivermectin and benzyl benzoate are contraindicated in pregnancy.

The image below shows a photo of a scabies burrow. The large scaly patch at the left is due to scratching. At the upper right, the scabies mite can be seen at the end of the burrow.

The Sarcoptes scabies mite is shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with tinea infection present with circular plaques with a sharp margin and raised edges that are itchy. 

The image below shows a lesion in tinea corporis.

Option C: Psoriasis presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scale, commonly affecting extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. It is often associated with nail changes and may involve systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis. Given below is an image of plaque psoriasis.

Option D: Photodermatosis refers to a group of skin conditions caused or exacerbated by exposure to sunlight or UV radiation. It can result in rashes, itching, or other skin reactions, often requiring sun protection or medical treatment.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below which is the investigation of choice in distal bowel tumours.
questions.solution:
Enteroclysis, which is the investigation of choice in patients with small bowel tumors.

Enteroclysis is a barium study in which the contrast agent is put directly into the duodenum through a nasogastric tube.

Continued infusion of 500 to 1000 mL of thin barium sulfate and methylcellulose suspension is done and then viewed continuously with the use of either fluoroscopy or radiographs taken at frequent intervals. This technique is a double-contrast procedure that allows detailed imaging of the entire small intestine.

Enteroclysis has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumors and is the investigation of choice, particularly for tumors located in the distal small bowel.

Advantages of enteroclysis:

  • The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel, bypassing the regulatory action of the pylorus.
  • The entire small bowel is demonstrated in a distended state, allowing better diagnosis. As a result of the dilatation, the following can be visualized:
    • Mild strictures
    • Small sinus tracts and fistulas
    • Minimal extrinsic compressions
    • Skip lesions
    • Proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases.
  • The examination can be completed in 15–30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a natural source of radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
X-rays are not a natural source of radiation exposure. They are artificially produced by linear accelerators.

Sources of radiation exposure:

Natural:

  • Cosmic rays
  • Environmental - terrestrial and atmospheric
  • Radioactive isotopes - of potassium (K-40) and carbon (C-14)

Man-made:

  • Medical and dental - X-rays, radioisotopes
  • Occupational exposure
  • Nuclear - radioactive fallout
